messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Wayne Fay <waynefay@...> wrote:
>
> I've been looking to add a code coverage tool to my new project's
> toolkit... Was looking at JCoverage, Clover, etc so this thread is
> very well-timed!
>
> I'm not hugely familiar with EMMA... Found the site easily
enough...
> Wondering if anyone here is using Maven2 + JUnit + EMMA and has any
> advice to offer? Or a sample pom.xml? :-)
>
> Wayne
>
> On 2/14/06, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
> > I'm not sure how you define "large scale" but we are
> > using JUnit with EMMA on the commercial product under
> > development right now. EMMA does everything we've
> > needed so far, and so I don't feel any design to change.
> > But there are definitely other good coverage tools out
> > there, too.
> >
> > The cost of implementation is very low, as is the cost
> > of switching. So why not go with EMMA for now and if
> > you find it doesn't do something you need, switch it
> > out later?
> >
> >
> > Todd.
> >
>

We looked at JCoverage and Clover also, but went with EMMA for cost
reasons. We use EMMA in conjunction with Ant and JUnit, and it has
served us well. The formatting and drilldown features of the HTML
reports are nice. The block coverage doesn't seem so reliable, but
class, method, and line coverage are solid.

Here's the relevant section from our build.xml:
<!-- ============================================================== -
->
<!-- Configure the Emma tasks
-->
<!--
============================================================== -->
<target name="prepare-emma" depends="init">
<!-- Creates the necessary directories for running emma against
Environment Management. -->
<!-- Creates the following directory structure
parent directory
|
+===docs
| \===emma
| \===html
\===test
\===junit
+===build
\===emma
-->
<mkdir dir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}"/>
<mkdir dir="${html.emma.doc.dir}"/>

<property name="emma.enabled" value="true" />
<!-- set out.instr.dir it is used by the emma task --
>
<property name="out.instr.dir"
value="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}" />
<!-- delay needed to make sure the copy is
finished. -->
<sleep seconds="2" />
<!-- define the emma task so ant knows about it -->
<taskdef resource="emma_ant.properties"
classpathref="prj.test.classpath" />
</target>

<!-- prj.classes.path - path to the compiled project files -->
<path id="prj.classes.path" >
<pathelement location="${classes.dir}" />
</path>

<target name="compile-emma" depends="prepare-emma">
<!-- runs junit and emma -->
<!-- creates instrumented class based on the compiled
project classes. -->
<emma enabled="${emma.enabled}" >
<instr instrpathref="prj.classes.path"
destdir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}"

metadatafile="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}/metadata.emma"
merge="true" />
</emma>
</target>

<!-- prj.emma.test.classpath - classpath used to run the emma
tests -->
<path id="prj.emma.test.classpath">
<pathelement path="${junit.build.junit.test.dir}"/>
<pathelement location="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}" />
<fileset dir="${emma.home}/lib" includes="*.jar"/>
<fileset dir="${junit.home}/lib" includes="*.jar"/>
<fileset dir="${junitdoclet.home}/lib" includes="*.jar"/>
<path refid="prj.test.classpath"/>
</path>

<target name="test-emma" depends="compile-emma">

<!-- runs junit by using the instrumented classes. -->
<junit printsummary="yes" fork="yes" haltonfailure="no"
showoutput="yes"
dir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}"
tempdir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}">
<jvmarg value="-
Demma.coverage.out.file=${emma.build.junit.test.dir}/coverage.emma" /
>
<jvmarg value="-Demma.coverage.out.merge=true" />
<classpath refid="prj.emma.test.classpath" />
<formatter type="xml" />
<batchtest todir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}">
<fileset dir="${junit.build.junit.test.dir}">
<include name="**/*Test.class"/>
<exclude name="**/*_*.class"/>
</fileset>
</batchtest>
</junit>
</target>

<target name="docs-emma" depends="build,prepare-test,compile-
test,test-emma, report-test">
<!-- documents the results of running the instrumented
classes. -->

<emma enabled="${emma.enabled}" >
<report sourcepath="${java.src.dir}">
<fileset dir="${emma.build.junit.test.dir}" >
<include name="*.emma" />
</fileset>
<txt
outfile="${emma.doc.dir}/coverage.txt" />
<html
outfile="${html.emma.doc.dir}/coverage.html" />
</report>
</emma>
